text: Forsyth County is a county located in the U.S. state of North Carolina. As of the 2020 census, the population was 382,590. It is the fourth-most populous county in North Carolina. Its county seat is Winston-Salem. == History == The county was made in 1849 from Stokes County. It was named after Colonel Benjamin Forsyth, who was killed in the War of 1812. == Bordering counties == These counties are bordered to Forsyth County: * Stokes County - north * Rockingham County - northeast * Guilford County - east * Davidson County - south * Davie County - southwest * Yadkin County - west * Surry County - northwest == Communities == These communities are in Forsyth County: === Cities === * Winston-Salem (county seat) * High Point (mostly in Guilford County, also in Randolph County, Davidson County) * King (mostly in Stokes County) === Towns === * Bethania * Kernersville (partially in Guilford County) * Lewisville * Rural Hall * Walkertown === Villages === * Clemmons * Tobaccoville (also in Stokes County) === Census-designated place === * Germanton === Unincorporated communities === * Belews Creek * Donnaha * Dozier * Pfafftown * Seward * Stanleyville * Union Cross * Vienna == References == == Other websites == * Forsyth County government official website Category:1840s establishments in North Carolina Category:1849 establishments in the United States Category:North Carolina counties
title: Forsyth County, North Carolina
